abstract: A Wired magazine reporter was accidentally sent a memorandum written by the company’s public relations firm to coach Microsoft executives on how to handle his questions.
snippet: A Wired magazine reporter was accidentally sent a memorandum written by the company’s public relations firm to coach Microsoft executives on how to handle his questions.
lead_paragraph: Journalists have an uneasy awareness that public relations professionals keep tabs on them, the better to hone the way they pitch and spin ideas for articles. And while the extent of this practice normally is not aired in public, it was last week when Wired magazine posted a long memo about one of its reporters that had been sent by e-mail to him by Microsoft, accidentally.

headline.main: A Misfired Memo Shows Close Tabs on Reporter
headline.print_headline: A Misfired Memo Shows Close Tabs on Reporter

abstract: ComScore, one of the leading companies that measures Web traffic, filed Monday to raise as much as $86.2 million in an initial public offering. Backed by the venture firm Accel Partners, which owns a 27 percent stake, comScore said it plans to use the proceeds for working capital, capital expenditures and possibly for acquisitions. ComScore, which competes with measurement firms such as NetRatings and Hitwise, reported $66.3 million in revenue in 2006. It said one customer, Microsoft, accounted for 12 percent of those revenues.
lead_paragraph: ComScore, one of the leading companies that measures Web traffic, filed Monday to raise as much as $86.2 million in an initial public offering. Backed by the venture firm Accel Partners, which owns a 27 percent stake, comScore said it plans to use the proceeds for working capital, capital expenditures and possibly for acquisitions. ComScore, which competes with measurement firms such as NetRatings and Hitwise, reported $66.3 million in revenue in 2006. It said one customer, Microsoft, accounted for 12 percent of those revenues.

headline.main: Web Measurement Firm ComScore to Go Public
